questions.text: When does puerperium begin?

choices.text: After the fourth stage of labour

questions.solution:
Puerperium begins as soon as the placenta is expelled and lasts for approximately 6 weeks.

It is the period following childbirth during which body tissues revert back approximately to the pre-pregnant state, both anatomically and physiologically.

Puerperium can be divided as follows:

  • Immediate puerperium: within 24 hours
  • Early puerperium: up to 7 days
  • Remote/late puerperium: up to 6 weeks or 42 days.

questions.text: How long does early puerperium last?
questions.solution:
Early puerperium is considered to last up to 1 week after delivery.

Puerperium can be divided as follows:

  • Immediate puerperium: within 24 hours
  • Early puerperium: up to 7 days
  • Remote/late puerperium: up to 6 weeks or 42 days

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding puerperium?

choices.text: The number of muscle fibres decrease
The uterus weighs 1000g by 1 week postpartum
There is decreased activity of uterine collagenase

questions.solution:
During puerperium, the number of muscle fibers is not decreased, but there is a substantial reduction in the myometrial cell size.

There is an increased activity of uterine collagenases and release of proteolytic enzymes.

Within the puerperal uterus, larger blood vessels become obliterated by hyaline changes. These vessels are gradually resorbed and replaced by smaller ones.

questions.text: External os reverts back to the pre-pregnant state by how many weeks?
questions.solution: External os never returns back to normal whereas the contour of the cervix takes 6 weeks to regain normalcy.

questions.text: Endometrial regeneration following delivery starts by which day?
questions.solution:
Endometrial regeneration starts by 7th day and is completed by the 10th day. Regeneration of the epithelium at the placental site takes about 6 weeks.

Endometrium regenerates from zona basalis which remains intact and is the source of new endometrium. This arises from proliferation of the endometrial glandular remnants and the stroma of the interglandular connective tissue.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman has just delivered a boy by spontaneous vaginal delivery. How often should her BP be recorded for the next 2 hours?
questions.solution:
For the first 2 hours following delivery, blood pressure and pulse should be recorded every 15 minutes. 

Temperature is assessed every 4 hours for the first 8 hours after delivery.

questions.text: A woman on post-natal day 1 presented with abdominal pain which worsens when she is breastfeeding. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of afterpains which are seen during puerperium.

In primiparous women, the uterus tends to remain tonically contracted following delivery. In multiparous women, it often contracts vigorously at intervals and gives rise to afterpains, which are similar to but milder than labor contractions.

These are more pronounced as parity increases and worsen when the infant suckles, likely because of oxytocin release. Afterpains gradually decrease in intensity and become mild by the third day.

questions.text: What would be the average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman?
questions.solution:
The average duration of lochial discharge in a postpartum woman is about 24-36 days. The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL.

The lochial discharge appears as follows:

Lochia rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia serosa Yellowish/Pink After 3-4 days

WBC, cervical mucus, microorganisms

questions.text: What is the contribution of postpartum diuresis to weight loss?
questions.solution:
Postpartum diuresis results in a relatively rapid weight loss of 2 to 3 kg.

Decreased estrogen levels are associated with the diuresis of excess extracellular fluid accumulated during pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Prolactin is the single most important galactopoietic hormone in postnatal women.

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh two days after vaginal delivery. Which nerve is likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. 

The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament. 

It is the most common obstetrical neuropathy after vaginal delivery, followed by femoral nerve involvement.

Note: The nerves most commonly injured during cesarean section are the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury?
questions.solution:
The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve causing foot drop.

The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is the most commonly injured nerve after vaginal delivery followed by femoral neuropathies. 

Obstetrical neuropathies are due to the pressure on branches of the lumbosacral nerve plexus during labor. They can manifest as complaints of intense neuralgia or cramp-like pains extending down one or both legs as soon as the head descends into the pelvis. Footdrop can be secondary to injury at the level of the lumbosacral plexus, sciatic nerve, or common fibular (peroneal) nerve. Injury of the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves may occur with cesarean delivery, which may manifest as an inguinal hernia and loss of sensation at the pubic region respectively.

Note: Since there are no options relating to intense neuralgia in the lower limb, foot drop becomes the best possible answer.

questions.text: Puerperal fever is defined as a temperature of _____.
questions.solution:
Puerperal fever is defined as the temperature of 38 °C or higher (100.4 °F) recorded on 2 separate occasions 24 hours apart within the first 10 days following delivery. This excludes the first 24 hours.

In the first 24 hours, a slight rise of temperature is not uncommon and hence the first 24 hours are excluded while defining puerperal pyrexia.

Note: Generally, fever in an adult is defined as an oral temperature of >37.5 °C.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with high-grade fever and foul-smelling lochia 2 days after vaginal delivery. Lower abdominal tenderness is elicited on examination. Her WBC count is 25,000/ microlitre. Which is the commonest route for the spread of her likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever, foul-smelling lochia, and pelvic tenderness is suggestive of puerperal sepsis. The most common route of spread of this condition is direct spread.

Streptococcus sp. is the most important causative organism of puerperal sepsis. The commonest manifestation is endometritis.

The route of delivery is an important risk factor for the development of puerperal sepsis (cesarean> vaginal). The most common site of puerperal infection is the placental site in vaginal delivery and uterine incision in cesarean section.

The only proven way of decreasing uterine infection following cesarean section is administrating a single dose of ampicillin or 1st generation cephalosporin at the time of caesarean delivery.

questions.text: What is the first line of treatment of mastitis in a lactating mother?
questions.solution:
Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers and should be taken for 10-14 days.

Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus. It is common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Clinical features of mastitis include:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Purulent nipple discharge
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Positive fluctuation test

A culture from nipple discharge or test-needle aspiration of the cellulitic area is done to confirm the organism and its antibiotic sensitivity. An ultrasonogram of the involved breast is done to exclude abscess. They are treated with antibiotics and adequate breast support. Choice of antibiotics in lactational mastitis:

  1. Dicloxacillin 500 mg 4 times a day is to be started empirically.
  2. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.
  3. If the infection is caused by resistant, penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus species then vancomycin, clindamycin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given for at least 10 days.

questions.text: A nursing mother in her third week postpartum presents with breast pain and difficulty in breastfeeding. On examination, warmth and tenderness over the left breast are noted. Her temperature is 38.3 °C and her WBC count is 13,000/mm3. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Most common etiological agent is streptococcus
Immediate source of infection is the infant's nose and throat

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of breast pain, fever, and leucocytosis with the image showing a red and swollen breast suggests a diagnosis of mastitis. The most common etiological agent is Staphylococcus aureus.

Mastitis refers to infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. Symptoms usually appear in the 3rd or 4th week. The infection is usually unilateral, with the source of infection being the infant's nose and throat. Predisposing factors are fissures, abrasions, and nipple cracks.

Management:

  • Breastfeeding should be continued. If the infant is unable to nurse on the inflamed breast, the mother may resort to breast pumping. When nursing bilaterally, suckling is best started on the uninvolved breast.
  • Dicloxacillin is the first line of treatment of mastitis. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin-sensitive.
  • If an abscess forms, surgical treatment is done.

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day, she came back with fever, tachycardia, and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation likely suggests cortical vein thrombosis.

Risk factors:

  • Pregnancy and puerperium
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Prothrombotic conditions

Most common clinical presentation is headache with or without vomiting, papilledema, or focal deficits.

Investigations:

  • Brain MRI with MR venography - most sensitive
  • CT - normal in 30 % of cases.

Option A: Subarachnoid hemorrhage - As there are no focal deficits, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Option B: Meningitis - The patient would have presented with neck rigidity or photophobia. Moreover, the presence of early papilledema goes against acute meningitis.

Option C: Acute migraine - It does not present with seizures.

questions.text: A mother, previously on OCPs, comes with her 2-week-old baby to the OPD. She informs you that she is currently breastfeeding her child and enquires about re-starting contraception. When would you recommend she start using contraceptives?
questions.solution:
Lactating women should start using contraceptives in the 3rd postpartum month. 

Progesterone-only methods are the hormonal contraception of choice in a lactating mother.

Efficacy of contraceptives used in postpartum period: Levonorgestrel IUD/ Implant > DMPA > Progestin-only pill.

Lactating mother Non-lactating mother
Ovulation occurs after 10 weeks Ovulation occurs after 4 weeks
Use contraceptive in 3rd post-partum month

Use contraceptive in 3rd post-partum week. 

Contraception should be ideally started after the resumption of ovulation. However, there are no contraindications for the use of contraceptives as early as 4-6 weeks in lactating women and immediately in non-lactating women.

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome. 

Sheehan's syndrome (SS) is postpartum hypopituitarism secondary to the necrosis of the pituitary gland. It usually results from severe hypotension or shock caused by massive hemorrhage during or after delivery. Patients with SS have varying degrees of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk of infarction. 

Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to a deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to a deficiency of gonadotropins). Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary-responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years.

It can present acutely as pituitary apoplexy, an endocrine emergency, characterized by a sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits, and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS hemorrhage, and death.

Also, it can present late with the following features:

  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids, later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids, vasopressin and growth hormones are given. If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out. Fertility can be achieved in these women with hMG and hCG. Clomiphene is ineffective. 

Option B: Rotor syndrome is a type of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia with autosomal recessive inheritance. Affected individuals have mild jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option C: Prolactinoma or pituitary adenoids is the condition of hyperprolactinemia diagnosed by a prolactin level >200 μg/L. It usually presents with infertility, amenorrhea, and galactorrhea.

Option D: Acromegaly is characterized by the signs and symptoms pertaining to excessive growth hormone secretion.

questions.text: A woman presents with fever on the 3rd postpartum day and is put on antibiotics. Fever is still not brought under control. On further investigation, she is diagnosed to have septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Antibiotics plus heparin is the next course of treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis.

Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis refers to the presence of an endovascular thrombus in the setting of associated bacterial or fungal infection.

The treatment of septic pelvic thrombophlebitis is broad-spectrum antibiotics plus anticoagulation. Anticoagulation is thought to prevent further thrombosis and reduce the spread of septic emboli.
